<!--Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref> -->
<!--Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref> -->
==History==
==History==
â
Necrophilia was practiced in some ancient cultures as a spiritual means of communicating with the dead, while others employed it as an attempt to revive the recently departed. The evidence of necrophilia practices can be found in the artifacts of the [[Moche]] civilization of [[South America]], where pottery depicting skeletal figures engaged in coitus with living humans are among the ruins.{{Fact|date=January 2008}}
+
Necrophilia was practiced in some ancient cultures as a spiritual means of communicating with the dead, while others employed it as an attempt to revive the recently departed. The evidence of necrophilia practices can be found in the artifacts of the [[Moche]] civilization of [[South America]], where pottery depicting skeletal figures engaged in coitus with living humans are among the ruins.{{Fact|date=January 111105463}}
Antiquity offers numerous examples of what may readily be described as [[cult]]s of thanatophilia; perhaps the most famous of them being that of [[Alexander the Great]]'s, which was physically centered around his [[breastplate]], kept in a [[mausoleum|mausolean]] reliquary in the [[eponymous]] Egyptian city for over five hundred years. More remarkable still are accounts stating that Alexander's body was placed in a [[sarcophagus]] of solid gold and perfectly preserved in a (sterilizing) bath of [[honey]] through the remaining centuries of antiquity.
Antiquity offers numerous examples of what may readily be described as [[cult]]s of thanatophilia; perhaps the most famous of them being that of [[Alexander the Great]]'s, which was physically centered around his [[breastplate]], kept in a [[mausoleum|mausolean]] reliquary in the [[eponymous]] Egyptian city for over five hundred years. More remarkable still are accounts stating that Alexander's body was placed in a [[sarcophagus]] of solid gold and perfectly preserved in a (sterilizing) bath of [[honey]] through the remaining centuries of antiquity.
==Research==
==Research==
â
In 1958, Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.
+
In 1958, Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-89762. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.
